Detailed Description

This is the Nemesis_IO_Helper class. Think of it as a big struct with storage for all the stuff one might want to pull from a Nemesis file. Derived from ExodusII_IO_Helper object, since Nemesis is based on the same file format.

Author
John W. Peterson
Date
2008

Definition at line 61 of file nemesis_io_helper.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ExodusVarType
inherited

Wraps calls to exII::ex_get_var_names() and exII::ex_get_var_param(). The enumeration controls whether nodal, elemental, or global variable names are read and which class members are filled in. NODAL: num_nodal_vars nodal_var_names ELEMENTAL: num_elem_vars elem_var_names GLOBAL: num_global_vars global_var_names

Enumerator
NODAL 
ELEMENTAL 
GLOBAL

Member Function Documentation

void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::build_element_and_node_maps ( const MeshBase &  pmesh)
private

This function builds the libmesh -> exodus and exodus -> libmesh node and element maps. These maps allow us to have a consistent numbering scheme within an Exodus file, given an existing globally consistent numbering scheme from LibMesh.

Definition at line 1706 of file nemesis_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_begin(), libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_end(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps::assign_conversion(), block_id_to_elem_connectivity, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::block_ids, libMesh::Elem::build(), libMesh::MeshBase::elem(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::exodus_node_num_to_libmesh, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion::get_canonical_type(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion::get_node_map(), libMesh::DofObject::id(), libMesh::libmesh_assert(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::libmesh_node_num_to_exodus, local_subdomain_counts, n_nodes, libMesh::Elem::n_nodes(), libMesh::Elem::node(), nodes_attached_to_local_elems, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::num_nodes, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::num_nodes_per_elem, libMesh::out, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), libMesh::Elem::subdomain_id(), subdomain_map, libMesh::Elem::type(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by initialize().

1707 {
1708  // If we don't have any local subdomains, it had better be because
1709  // we don't have any local elements
1710 #ifdef DEBUG
1711  if (local_subdomain_counts.empty())
1712  {
1713  libmesh_assert(pmesh.active_local_elements_begin() ==
1714  pmesh.active_local_elements_end());
1715  libmesh_assert(this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.empty());
1716  }
1717 #endif
1718 
1719  // Elements have to be numbered contiguously based on what block
1720  // number they are in. Therefore we have to do a bit of work to get
1721  // the block (ie subdomain) numbers first and store them off as
1722  // block_ids.
1723 
1724  // Make sure there is no leftover information in the subdomain_map, and reserve
1725  // enough space to store the elements we need.
1726  this->subdomain_map.clear();
1727  for (std::map<subdomain_id_type, unsigned>::iterator it=this->local_subdomain_counts.begin();
1728  it != this->local_subdomain_counts.end();
1729  ++it)
1730  {
1731  subdomain_id_type cur_subdomain = (*it).first;
1732 
1733  /*
1734  // We can't have a zero subdomain ID in Exodus (for some reason?)
1735  // so map zero subdomains to a max value...
1736  if (cur_subdomain == 0)
1737  cur_subdomain = std::numeric_limits<subdomain_id_type>::max();
1738  */
1739 
1740  if (verbose)
1741  {
1742  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] "
1743  << "local_subdomain_counts [" << static_cast<unsigned>(cur_subdomain) << "]= "
1744  << (*it).second
1745  << std::endl;
1746  }
1747 
1748  // *it.first is the subodmain ID, *it.second is the number of elements it contains
1749  this->subdomain_map[ cur_subdomain ].reserve( (*it).second );
1750  }
1751 
1752 
1753  // First loop over the elements to figure out which elements are in which subdomain
1754  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_it = pmesh.active_local_elements_begin();
1755  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_end = pmesh.active_local_elements_end();
1756 
1757  for (; elem_it != elem_end; ++elem_it)
1758  {
1759  const Elem * elem = *elem_it;
1760 
1761  // Grab the nodes while we're here.
1762  for (unsigned int n=0; n<elem->n_nodes(); ++n)
1763  this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.insert( elem->node(n) );
1764 
1765  subdomain_id_type cur_subdomain = elem->subdomain_id();
1766 
1767  /*
1768  // We can't have a zero subdomain ID in Exodus (for some reason?)
1769  // so map zero subdomains to a max value...
1770  if(cur_subdomain == 0)
1771  cur_subdomain = std::numeric_limits<subdomain_id_type>::max();
1772  */
1773 
1774  this->subdomain_map[cur_subdomain].push_back
1775  (cast_int<unsigned>(elem->id()));
1776  }
1777 
1778  // Set num_nodes which is used by exodusII_io_helper
1779  this->num_nodes =
1780  cast_int<int>(this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.size());
1781 
1782  // Now come up with a 1-based numbering for these nodes
1783  this->exodus_node_num_to_libmesh.clear(); // Make sure it's empty
1784  this->exodus_node_num_to_libmesh.reserve(this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.size());
1785 
1786  // Also make sure there's no leftover information in the map which goes the
1787  // other direction.
1788  this->libmesh_node_num_to_exodus.clear();
1789 
1790  // Set the map for nodes
1791  for (std::set<int>::iterator it = this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.begin();
1792  it != this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.end();
1793  ++it)
1794  {
1795  // I.e. given exodus_node_id,
1796  // exodus_node_num_to_libmesh[ exodus_node_id ] returns the libmesh ID for that node.
1797  // Note that even though most of Exodus is 1-based, this code will map an Exodus ID of
1798  // zero to some libmesh node ID. Is that a problem?
1799  this->exodus_node_num_to_libmesh.push_back(*it);
1800 
1801  // Likewise, given libmesh_node_id,
1802  // libmesh_node_num_to_exodus[ libmesh_node_id ] returns the *Exodus* ID for that node.
1803  // Unlike the exodus_node_num_to_libmesh vector above, this one is a std::map
1804  this->libmesh_node_num_to_exodus[*it] =
1805  cast_int<int>(this->exodus_node_num_to_libmesh.size()); // should never be zero...
1806  }
1807 
1808  // Now we're going to loop over the subdomain map and build a few things right
1809  // now that we'll use later.
1810 
1811  // First make sure our data structures don't have any leftover data...
1812  this->exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh.clear();
1813  this->block_ids.clear();
1814  this->libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus.clear();
1815 
1816  // Now loop over each subdomain and get a unique numbering for the elements
1817  for (std::map<subdomain_id_type, std::vector<unsigned int> >::iterator it = this->subdomain_map.begin();
1818  it != this->subdomain_map.end();
1819  ++it)
1820  {
1821  block_ids.push_back((*it).first);
1822 
1823  // Vector of element IDs for this subdomain
1824  std::vector<unsigned int>& elem_ids_this_subdomain = (*it).second;
1825 
1826  // The code below assumes this subdomain block is not empty, make sure that's the case!
1827  if (elem_ids_this_subdomain.size() == 0)
1828  libmesh_error_msg("Error, no element IDs found in subdomain " << (*it).first);
1829 
1830  ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps em(*this);
1831 
1832  // Use the first element in this block to get representative information.
1833  // Note that Exodus assumes all elements in a block are of the same type!
1834  // We are using that same assumption here!
1835  const ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion conv = em.assign_conversion(pmesh.elem(elem_ids_this_subdomain[0])->type());
1836  this->num_nodes_per_elem = pmesh.elem(elem_ids_this_subdomain[0])->n_nodes();
1837 
1838  // Get a reference to the connectivity vector for this subdomain. This vector
1839  // is most likely empty, we are going to fill it up now.
1840  std::vector<int>& current_block_connectivity = this->block_id_to_elem_connectivity[(*it).first];
1841 
1842  // Just in case it's not already empty...
1843  current_block_connectivity.clear();
1844  current_block_connectivity.resize(elem_ids_this_subdomain.size() * this->num_nodes_per_elem);
1845 
1846  for (unsigned int i=0; i<elem_ids_this_subdomain.size(); i++)
1847  {
1848  unsigned int elem_id = elem_ids_this_subdomain[i];
1849 
1850  // Set the number map for elements
1851  this->exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh.push_back(elem_id);
1852  this->libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus[elem_id] =
1853  cast_int<int>(this->exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh.size());
1854 
1855  const Elem * elem = pmesh.elem(elem_id);
1856 
1857  // Exodus/Nemesis want every block to have the same element type
1858  // libmesh_assert_equal_to (elem->type(), conv.get_canonical_type());
1859 
1860  // But we can get away with writing e.g. HEX8 and INFHEX8 in
1861  // the same block...
1862  libmesh_assert_equal_to (elem->n_nodes(), Elem::build(conv.get_canonical_type(), NULL)->n_nodes());
1863 
1864  for (unsigned int j=0; j < static_cast<unsigned int>(this->num_nodes_per_elem); j++)
1865  {
1866  const unsigned int connect_index = (i*this->num_nodes_per_elem)+j;
1867  const unsigned int elem_node_index = conv.get_node_map(j);
1868  current_block_connectivity[connect_index] = this->libmesh_node_num_to_exodus[elem->node(elem_node_index)];
1869  }
1870  } // End loop over elems in this subdomain
1871  } // end loop over subdomain_map
1872 }

void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::compute_border_node_ids ( const MeshBase &  pmesh)
private

This function constructs the set of border node IDs present on the current mesh. These are nodes which live on the "border" between elements which live on different processors.

Definition at line 1878 of file nemesis_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::active_elements_begin(), libMesh::MeshBase::active_elements_end(), border_node_ids, libMesh::libmesh_assert(), libMesh::Elem::n_nodes(), libMesh::ParallelObject::n_processors(), libMesh::Elem::node(), num_border_nodes, num_node_cmaps, libMesh::out, proc_nodes_touched_intersections, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), libMesh::DofObject::processor_id(), libMesh::Parallel::set_union(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by initialize().

1879 {
1880  // The set which will eventually contain the IDs of "border nodes". These are nodes
1881  // that lie on the boundary between one or more processors.
1882  //std::set<unsigned> border_node_ids;
1883 
1884  // map from processor ID to set of nodes which elements from this processor "touch",
1885  // that is,
1886  // proc_nodes_touched[p] = (set all node IDs found in elements owned by processor p)
1887  std::map<unsigned, std::set<unsigned> > proc_nodes_touched;
1888 
1889 
1890  // We are going to create a lot of intermediate data structures here, so make sure
1891  // as many as possible all cleaned up by creating scope!
1892  {
1893  // Loop over active (not just active local) elements, make sets of node IDs for each
1894  // processor which has an element that "touches" a node.
1895  {
1896  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_it = pmesh.active_elements_begin();
1897  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_end = pmesh.active_elements_end();
1898 
1899  for (; elem_it != elem_end; ++elem_it)
1900  {
1901  const Elem* elem = *elem_it;
1902 
1903  // Get reference to the set for this processor. If it does not exist
1904  // it will be created.
1905  std::set<unsigned>& set_p = proc_nodes_touched[ elem->processor_id() ];
1906 
1907  // Insert all nodes touched by this element into the set
1908  for (unsigned int node=0; node<elem->n_nodes(); ++node)
1909  set_p.insert(elem->node(node));
1910  }
1911  }
1912 
1913  // The number of node communication maps is the number of other processors
1914  // with which we share nodes. (I think.) This is just the size of the map we just
1915  // created, minus 1.
1916  this->num_node_cmaps =
1917  cast_int<int>(proc_nodes_touched.size() - 1);
1918 
1919  // If we've got no elements on this processor and haven't touched
1920  // any nodes, however, then that's 0 other processors with which
1921  // we share nodes, not -1.
1922  if (this->num_node_cmaps == -1)
1923  {
1924  libmesh_assert (pmesh.active_elements_begin() == pmesh.active_elements_end());
1925  this->num_node_cmaps = 0;
1926  }
1927 
1928  // We can't be connecting to more processors than exist outside
1929  // ourselves
1930  libmesh_assert_less (static_cast<unsigned>(this->num_node_cmaps), this->n_processors());
1931 
1932  if (verbose)
1933  {
1934  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
1935  << "] proc_nodes_touched contains "
1936  << proc_nodes_touched.size()
1937  << " sets of nodes."
1938  << std::endl;
1939 
1940  for (proc_nodes_touched_iterator it = proc_nodes_touched.begin();
1941  it != proc_nodes_touched.end();
1942  ++it)
1943  {
1944  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
1945  << "] proc_nodes_touched[" << (*it).first << "] has "
1946  << (*it).second.size()
1947  << " entries."
1948  << std::endl;
1949  }
1950  }
1951 
1952 
1953  // Loop over all the sets we just created and compute intersections with the
1954  // this processor's set. Obviously, don't intersect with ourself.
1955  for (proc_nodes_touched_iterator it = proc_nodes_touched.begin();
1956  it != proc_nodes_touched.end();
1957  ++it)
1958  {
1959  // Don't compute intersections with ourself
1960  if ((*it).first == this->processor_id())
1961  continue;
1962 
1963  // Otherwise, compute intersection with other processor and ourself
1964  std::set<unsigned>& my_set = proc_nodes_touched[this->processor_id()];
1965  std::set<unsigned>& other_set = (*it).second;
1966  std::set<unsigned>& result_set = this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections[ (*it).first ]; // created if does not exist
1967 
1968  std::set_intersection(my_set.begin(), my_set.end(),
1969  other_set.begin(), other_set.end(),
1970  std::inserter(result_set, result_set.end()));
1971  }
1972 
1973  if (verbose)
1974  {
1975  for (proc_nodes_touched_iterator it = this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.begin();
1976  it != this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.end();
1977  ++it)
1978  {
1979  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
1980  << "] this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections[" << (*it).first << "] has "
1981  << (*it).second.size()
1982  << " entries."
1983  << std::endl;
1984  }
1985  }
1986 
1987  // Compute the set_union of all the preceding intersections. This will be the set of
1988  // border node IDs for this processor.
1989  for (proc_nodes_touched_iterator it = this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.begin();
1990  it != this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.end();
1991  ++it)
1992  {
1993  std::set<unsigned>& other_set = (*it).second;
1994  std::set<unsigned> intermediate_result; // Don't think we can insert into one of the sets we're unioning...
1995 
1996  std::set_union(this->border_node_ids.begin(), this->border_node_ids.end(),
1997  other_set.begin(), other_set.end(),
1998  std::inserter(intermediate_result, intermediate_result.end()));
1999 
2000  // Swap our intermediate result into the final set
2001  this->border_node_ids.swap(intermediate_result);
2002  }
2003 
2004  if (verbose)
2005  {
2006  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
2007  << "] border_node_ids.size()=" << this->border_node_ids.size()
2008  << std::endl;
2009  }
2010  } // end scope for border node ID creation
2011 
2012  // Store the number of border node IDs to be written to Nemesis file
2013  this->num_border_nodes = cast_int<int>(this->border_node_ids.size());
2014 }

void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::compute_communication_map_parameters ( )
private

This function determines the communication map parameters which will eventually be written to file

Referenced by initialize().

1135 {
1136  // For the nodes, these are the number of entries in the sets in proc_nodes_touched_intersections
1137  // map computed above. Note: this map does not contain self-intersections so we can loop over it
1138  // directly.
1139  this->node_cmap_node_cnts.clear(); // Make sure we don't have any leftover information...
1140  this->node_cmap_ids.clear(); // Make sure we don't have any leftover information...
1141  this->node_cmap_node_cnts.resize(this->num_node_cmaps);
1142  this->node_cmap_ids.resize(this->num_node_cmaps);
1143 
1144  {
1145  unsigned cnt=0; // Index into the vector
1146  for (proc_nodes_touched_iterator it = this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.begin();
1147  it != this->proc_nodes_touched_intersections.end();
1148  ++it)
1149  {
1150  this->node_cmap_ids[cnt] = (*it).first; // The ID of the proc we communicate with
1151  this->node_cmap_node_cnts[cnt] =
1152  cast_int<int>((*it).second.size()); // The number of nodes we communicate
1153  cnt++; // increment vector index!
1154  }
1155  }
1156 
1157  // Print the packed vectors we just filled
1158  if (verbose)
1159  {
1160  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] node_cmap_node_cnts = ";
1161  for (unsigned i=0; i<node_cmap_node_cnts.size(); ++i)
1162  libMesh::out << node_cmap_node_cnts[i] << ", ";
1163  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1164 
1165  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] node_cmap_ids = ";
1166  for (unsigned i=0; i<node_cmap_ids.size(); ++i)
1167  libMesh::out << node_cmap_ids[i] << ", ";
1168  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1169  }
1170 
1171  // For the elements, we have not yet computed all this information..
1172  this->elem_cmap_elem_cnts.clear(); // Make sure we don't have any leftover information...
1173  this->elem_cmap_ids.clear(); // Make sure we don't have any leftover information...
1174  this->elem_cmap_elem_cnts.resize(this->num_elem_cmaps);
1175  this->elem_cmap_ids.resize(this->num_elem_cmaps);
1176 
1177  // Pack the elem_cmap_ids and elem_cmap_elem_cnts vectors
1178  {
1179  unsigned cnt=0; // Index into the vectors we're filling
1180  for (proc_border_elem_sets_iterator it = this->proc_border_elem_sets.begin();
1181  it != this->proc_border_elem_sets.end();
1182  ++it)
1183  {
1184  this->elem_cmap_ids[cnt] = (*it).first; // The ID of the proc we communicate with
1185  this->elem_cmap_elem_cnts[cnt] =
1186  cast_int<int>((*it).second.size()); // The number of elems we communicate to/from that proc
1187  cnt++; // increment vector index!
1188  }
1189  }
1190 
1191  // Print the packed vectors we just filled
1192  if (verbose)
1193  {
1194  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] elem_cmap_elem_cnts = ";
1195  for (unsigned i=0; i<elem_cmap_elem_cnts.size(); ++i)
1196  libMesh::out << elem_cmap_elem_cnts[i] << ", ";
1197  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1198 
1199  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] elem_cmap_ids = ";
1200  for (unsigned i=0; i<elem_cmap_ids.size(); ++i)
1201  libMesh::out << elem_cmap_ids[i] << ", ";
1202  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1203  }
1204 }

995  it != this->proc_border_elem_sets.end();
996  ++it)

998  // Make sure the current elem_cmap_id matches the index in our map of node intersections
999  libmesh_assert_equal_to ( static_cast<unsigned>(this->elem_cmap_ids[cnt]), (*it).first );

1002  std::set<std::pair<unsigned,unsigned> >& elem_set = (*it).second;

1006  this->elem_cmap_side_ids[cnt].resize(elem_set.size());

1012  for (unsigned j=0; j<this->elem_cmap_elem_ids[cnt].size(); ++j, ++elem_set_iter)
1013  {
1014  this->elem_cmap_elem_ids[cnt][j] = libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus[(*elem_set_iter).first];// + 1; // Elem ID, Exodus is 1-based
1015  this->elem_cmap_side_ids[cnt][j] = (*elem_set_iter).second; // Side ID, this has already been converted above

1017  }
1018 
1019  cnt++;// increment vector index to go to next processor
1020  }
1021  } // end scope for packing

void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::compute_internal_and_border_elems_and_internal_nodes ( const MeshBase &  pmesh)
private

This function constructs the set of border and internal element IDs and internal node IDs present on the current mesh.

Definition at line 1210 of file nemesis_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_begin(), libMesh::MeshBase::active_local_elements_end(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps::assign_conversion(), border_elem_ids, border_node_ids, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion::get_inverse_side_map(), libMesh::DofObject::id(), internal_elem_ids, internal_node_ids, libMesh::Elem::n_neighbors(), libMesh::Elem::n_nodes(), libMesh::Elem::neighbor(), libMesh::Elem::node(), nodes_attached_to_local_elems, num_border_elems, num_border_nodes, num_elem_cmaps, num_internal_elems, num_internal_nodes, libMesh::out, proc_border_elem_sets, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), libMesh::DofObject::processor_id(), libMesh::Elem::type(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by initialize().

1211 {
1212  // Set of all local, active element IDs. After we have identified border element
1213  // IDs, the set_difference between this set and the border_elem_ids set will give us
1214  // the set of internal_elem_ids.
1215  std::set<unsigned> all_elem_ids;
1216 
1217  // A set of processor IDs which elements on this processor have as
1218  // neighbors. The size of this set will determine the number of
1219  // element communication maps in Exodus.
1220  std::set<unsigned> neighboring_processor_ids;
1221 
1222  // Will be used to create conversion objects capable of mapping libmesh
1223  // element numberings into Nemesis numberings.
1224  ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps element_mapper(*this);
1225 
1226  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_it = pmesh.active_local_elements_begin();
1227  MeshBase::const_element_iterator elem_end = pmesh.active_local_elements_end();
1228 
1229  for (; elem_it != elem_end; ++elem_it)
1230  {
1231  const Elem* elem = *elem_it;
1232 
1233  // Add this Elem's ID to all_elem_ids, later we will take the difference
1234  // between this set and the set of border_elem_ids, to get the set of
1235  // internal_elem_ids.
1236  all_elem_ids.insert(elem->id());
1237 
1238  // Will be set to true if element is determined to be a border element
1239  bool is_border_elem = false;
1240 
1241  // Construct a conversion object for this Element. This will help us map
1242  // Libmesh numberings into Nemesis numberings for sides.
1243  ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion conv = element_mapper.assign_conversion(elem->type());
1244 
1245  // Add all this element's node IDs to the set of all node IDs.
1246  // The set of internal_node_ids will be the set difference between
1247  // the set of all nodes and the set of border nodes.
1248  //
1249  // In addition, if any node of a local node is listed in the
1250  // border nodes list, then this element goes into the proc_border_elem_sets.
1251  // Note that there is not a 1:1 correspondence between
1252  // border_elem_ids and the entries which go into proc_border_elem_sets.
1253  // The latter is for communication purposes, ie determining which elements
1254  // should be shared between processors.
1255  for (unsigned int node=0; node<elem->n_nodes(); ++node)
1256  {
1257  this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.insert(elem->node(node));
1258  } // end loop over element's nodes
1259 
1260  // Loop over element's neighbors, see if it has a neighbor which is off-processor
1261  for (unsigned int n=0; n<elem->n_neighbors(); ++n)
1262  {
1263  if (elem->neighbor(n) != NULL)
1264  {
1265  unsigned neighbor_proc_id = elem->neighbor(n)->processor_id();
1266 
1267  // If my neighbor has a different processor ID, I must be a border element.
1268  // Also track the neighboring processor ID if it is are different from our processor ID
1269  if (neighbor_proc_id != this->processor_id())
1270  {
1271  is_border_elem = true;
1272  neighboring_processor_ids.insert(neighbor_proc_id);
1273 
1274  // Convert libmesh side(n) of this element into a side ID for Nemesis
1275  unsigned nemesis_side_id = conv.get_inverse_side_map(n);
1276 
1277  if (verbose)
1278  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] LibMesh side "
1279  << n
1280  << " mapped to (1-based) Exodus side "
1281  << nemesis_side_id
1282  << std::endl;
1283 
1284  // Add this element's ID and the ID of the side which is on the boundary
1285  // to the set of border elements for this processor.
1286  // Note: if the set does not already exist, this creates it.
1287  this->proc_border_elem_sets[ neighbor_proc_id ].insert( std::make_pair(elem->id(), nemesis_side_id) );
1288  }
1289  }
1290  } // end for loop over neighbors
1291 
1292  // If we're on a border element, add it to the set
1293  if (is_border_elem)
1294  this->border_elem_ids.insert( elem->id() );
1295 
1296  } // end for loop over active local elements
1297 
1298  // Take the set_difference between all elements and border elements to get internal
1299  // element IDs
1300  std::set_difference(all_elem_ids.begin(), all_elem_ids.end(),
1301  this->border_elem_ids.begin(), this->border_elem_ids.end(),
1302  std::inserter(this->internal_elem_ids, this->internal_elem_ids.end()));
1303 
1304  // Take the set_difference between all nodes and border nodes to get internal nodes
1305  std::set_difference(this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.begin(), this->nodes_attached_to_local_elems.end(),
1306  this->border_node_ids.begin(), this->border_node_ids.end(),
1307  std::inserter(this->internal_node_ids, this->internal_node_ids.end()));
1308 
1309  if (verbose)
1310  {
1311  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] neighboring_processor_ids = ";
1312  for (std::set<unsigned>::iterator it = neighboring_processor_ids.begin();
1313  it != neighboring_processor_ids.end();
1314  ++it)
1315  {
1316  libMesh::out << *it << " ";
1317  }
1318  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1319  }
1320 
1321  // The size of the neighboring_processor_ids set should be the number of element communication maps
1322  this->num_elem_cmaps =
1323  cast_int<int>(neighboring_processor_ids.size());
1324 
1325  if (verbose)
1326  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] "
1327  << "Number of neighboring processor IDs="
1328  << this->num_elem_cmaps
1329  << std::endl;
1330 
1331  if (verbose)
1332  {
1333  // Print out counts of border elements for each processor
1334  for (proc_border_elem_sets_iterator it=this->proc_border_elem_sets.begin();
1335  it != this->proc_border_elem_sets.end(); ++it)
1336  {
1337  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] "
1338  << "Proc "
1339  << (*it).first << " communicates "
1340  << (*it).second.size() << " elements." << std::endl;
1341  }
1342  }
1343 
1344  // Store the number of internal and border elements, and the number of internal nodes,
1345  // to be written to the Nemesis file.
1346  this->num_internal_elems =
1347  cast_int<int>(this->internal_elem_ids.size());
1348  this->num_border_elems =
1349  cast_int<int>(this->border_elem_ids.size());
1350  this->num_internal_nodes =
1351  cast_int<int>(this->internal_node_ids.size());
1352 
1353  if (verbose)
1354  {
1355  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] num_internal_nodes=" << this->num_internal_nodes << std::endl;
1356  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] num_border_nodes=" << this->num_border_nodes << std::endl;
1357  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] num_border_elems=" << this->num_border_elems << std::endl;
1358  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] num_internal_elems=" << this->num_internal_elems << std::endl;
1359  }
1360 }

1632  global_subdomain_ids.end());

1662  // subdomain IDs, so pack them into a vector one by one. Use a vector of int since

1668  it != global_subdomain_ids.end(); ++it)
1669  {
1670  // Find the entry in the local map, note: if not found, will be created with 0 default value, which is OK...
1671  this->global_elem_blk_cnts[cnt++] = global_subdomain_counts[*it];
1672  }
1673

1675  this->comm().sum(this->global_elem_blk_cnts);
1676

1678  {

1682  libMesh::out << std::endl;

1475  std::set<boundary_id_type> local_node_boundary_ids;

1517  pmesh.get_boundary_info().build_node_list
1518  (boundary_node_list, boundary_node_boundary_id_list);
1519 
1520  if (verbose)
1521  {
1522  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] boundary_node_list.size()="
1523  << boundary_node_list.size() << std::endl;

1525  for (unsigned i=0; i<boundary_node_list.size(); ++i)
1526  {

1528  }
1529  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1530  }
1531 
1532  // Now get the global information. In this case, we only want to count boundary
1533  // information for nodes *owned* by this processor, so there are no duplicates.
1534 
1535  // Make sure we don't have any left over information
1536  this->num_global_node_counts.clear();
1537  this->num_global_node_counts.resize(this->global_nodeset_ids.size());
1538 
1539  // Unfortunately, we can't just count up all occurrences of a given id,
1540  // that would give us duplicate entries when we do the parallel summation.
1541  // So instead, only count entries for nodes owned by this processor.
1542  // Start by getting rid of all non-local node entries from the vectors.
1543  std::vector<dof_id_type>::iterator it_node=boundary_node_list.begin();
1544  std::vector<boundary_id_type>::iterator it_id=boundary_node_boundary_id_list.begin();
1545 
1546  // New end iterators, to be updated as we find non-local IDs
1547  std::vector<dof_id_type>::iterator new_node_list_end = boundary_node_list.end();
1548  std::vector<boundary_id_type>::iterator new_boundary_id_list_end = boundary_node_boundary_id_list.end();
1549  for ( ; it_node != new_node_list_end; )
1550  {
1551  if (pmesh.node_ptr( *it_node )->processor_id() != this->processor_id())
1552  {
1553  // Back up the new end iterators to prepare for swap
1554  --new_node_list_end;
1555  --new_boundary_id_list_end;
1556 
1557  // Swap places, the non-local node will now be "past-the-end"
1558  std::swap (*it_node, *new_node_list_end);
1559  std::swap (*it_id, *new_boundary_id_list_end);
1560  }
1561  else // node is local, go to next
1562  {
1563  ++it_node;
1564  ++it_id;
1565  }
1566  }
1567 
1568  // Erase from "new" end to old end on each vector.
1569  boundary_node_list.erase(new_node_list_end, boundary_node_list.end());
1570  boundary_node_boundary_id_list.erase(new_boundary_id_list_end, boundary_node_boundary_id_list.end());
1571 
1572  // Now we can do the local count for each ID...
1573  for (unsigned i=0; i<global_nodeset_ids.size(); ++i)
1574  {
1575  this->num_global_node_counts[i] = cast_int<int>
1576  (std::count(boundary_node_boundary_id_list.begin(),
1577  boundary_node_boundary_id_list.end(),
1578  cast_int<boundary_id_type>(this->global_nodeset_ids[i])));
1579  }
1580 
1581  // And finally we can sum them up
1582  this->comm().sum(this->num_global_node_counts);
1583 
1584  if (verbose)
1585  {
1586  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] num_global_node_counts = ";
1587  for (unsigned i=0; i<num_global_node_counts.size(); ++i)
1588  libMesh::out << num_global_node_counts[i] << ", ";
1589  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1590  }
1591 }

1408

1410  {

1412  {

1414  --new_bndry_elem_list_end;

1420  std::swap (*it_side, *new_bndry_side_list_end);
1421  std::swap (*it_id, *new_bndry_id_list_end);
1422  }
1423  else // elem is local, go to next
1424  {
1425  ++it_elem;
1426  ++it_side;
1427  ++it_id;
1428  }
1429  }
1430 
1431  // Erase from "new" end to old end on each vector.
1432  bndry_elem_list.erase(new_bndry_elem_list_end, bndry_elem_list.end());
1433  bndry_side_list.erase(new_bndry_side_list_end, bndry_side_list.end());

1437  this->num_global_side_counts.resize(this->global_sideset_ids.size());
1438

1441  {

1443  (std::count(bndry_id_list.begin(),
1444  bndry_id_list.end(),
1445  cast_int<boundary_id_type>(this->global_sideset_ids[i])));
1446  }
1447

1449  {

1453  libMesh::out << std::endl;
1454  }
1455

std::string libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::construct_nemesis_filename ( const std::string &  base_filename)

Given base_filename, foo.e, constructs the Nemesis filename foo.e.X.Y, where X=n. CPUs and Y=processor ID

Definition at line 2473 of file nemesis_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::ParallelObject::n_processors(), libMesh::out, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by libMesh::Nemesis_IO::read(), libMesh::Nemesis_IO::write(), and libMesh::Nemesis_IO::write_nodal_data().

2474 {
2475  // Build a filename for this processor. This code is cut-n-pasted from the read function
2476  // and should probably be put into a separate function...
2477  std::ostringstream file_oss;
2478 
2479  // We have to be a little careful here: Nemesis left pads its file
2480  // numbers based on the number of processors, so for example on 10
2481  // processors, we'd have:
2482  // mesh.e.10.00
2483  // mesh.e.10.01
2484  // mesh.e.10.02
2485  // ...
2486  // mesh.e.10.09
2487 
2488  // And on 100 you'd have:
2489  // mesh.e.100.000
2490  // mesh.e.100.001
2491  // ...
2492  // mesh.e.128.099
2493 
2494  // Find the length of the highest processor ID
2495  file_oss << (this->n_processors());
2496  unsigned int field_width = cast_int<unsigned int>(file_oss.str().size());
2497 
2498  if (verbose)
2499  libMesh::out << "field_width=" << field_width << std::endl;
2500 
2501  file_oss.str(""); // reset the string stream
2502  file_oss << base_filename
2503  << '.' << this->n_processors()
2504  << '.' << std::setfill('0') << std::setw(field_width) << this->processor_id();
2505 
2506  // Return the resulting string
2507  return file_oss.str();
2508 }

711 {
712  // Fall back on double precision when necessary since ExodusII
713  // doesn't seem to support long double
714  int
715  comp_ws = 0,
716  io_ws = 0;
717 
718  if(_single_precision)
719  {
720  comp_ws = sizeof(float);
721  io_ws = sizeof(float);
722  }
723  else
724  {
725  comp_ws = cast_int<int>(std::min(sizeof(Real), sizeof(double)));
726  io_ws = cast_int<int>(std::min(sizeof(Real), sizeof(double)));
727  }

inherited

Returns a vector with three copies of each element in the provided name vector, starting with r_, i_ and a_ respectively.

Definition at line 1863 of file exodusII_io_helper.C.

Referenced by libMesh::ExodusII_IO::write_element_data(), libMesh::Nemesis_IO::write_global_data(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO::write_global_data(), libMesh::Nemesis_IO::write_nodal_data(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO::write_nodal_data(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO::write_nodal_data_discontinuous().

1864 {
1865  std::vector<std::string>::const_iterator names_it = names.begin();
1866  std::vector<std::string>::const_iterator names_end = names.end();
1867 
1868  std::vector<std::string> complex_names;
1869 
1870  // This will loop over all names and create new "complex" names
1871  // (i.e. names that start with r_, i_ or a_
1872  for (; names_it != names_end; ++names_it)
1873  {
1874  std::stringstream name_real, name_imag, name_abs;
1875  name_real << "r_" << *names_it;
1876  name_imag << "i_" << *names_it;
1877  name_abs << "a_" << *names_it;
1878 
1879  complex_names.push_back(name_real.str());
1880  complex_names.push_back(name_imag.str());
1881  complex_names.push_back(name_abs.str());
1882  }
1883

void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::get_init_global ( )

Reading functions. These just allocate memory for you and call the Nemesis routines of the same name. They also handle error checking for the Nemesis return value. Be careful calling these at random, some depend on others being called first... Fills: num_nodes_global, num_elems_global, num_elem_blks_global, num_node_sets_global, num_side_sets_global Call after: read_header() Call before: Any other get_* function from this class

Referenced by libMesh::Nemesis_IO::read().

749  // const ParallelMesh& pmesh = cast_ref<const ParallelMesh&>(mesh);
750  const MeshBase& pmesh = mesh;
751 
752  // According to Nemesis documentation, first call when writing should be to
753  // ne_put_init_info(). Our reader doesn't actually call this, but we should
754  // strive to be as close to a normal nemesis file as possible...
755  this->put_init_info(this->n_processors(), 1, "p");
756 
757 
758  // Gather global "initial" information for Nemesis. This consists of
759  // three parts labelled I, II, and III below...
760 
761  //
762  // I.) Need to compute the number of global element blocks. To be consistent with
763  // Exodus, we also incorrectly associate the number of element blocks with the
764  // number of libmesh subdomains...
765  //
766  this->compute_num_global_elem_blocks(pmesh);
767 
768  //
769  // II.) Determine the global number of nodesets by communication.
770  // This code relies on BoundaryInfo storing side and node
771  // boundary IDs separately at the time they are added to the
772  // BoundaryInfo object.
773  //
774  this->compute_num_global_nodesets(pmesh);
775 
776  //
777  // III.) Need to compute the global number of sidesets by communication:
778  // This code relies on BoundaryInfo storing side and node
779  // boundary IDs separately at the time they are added to the
780  // BoundaryInfo object.
781  //
782  this->compute_num_global_sidesets(pmesh);
783 
784  // Now write the global data obtained in steps I, II, and III to the Nemesis file
785  this->put_init_global(pmesh.parallel_n_nodes(),
786  pmesh.parallel_n_elem(),
787  this->num_elem_blks_global, /* I. */
788  this->num_node_sets_global, /* II. */
789  this->num_side_sets_global /* III. */
790  );
791 
792  // Next, we'll write global element block information to the file. This was already
793  // gathered in step I. above
794  this->put_eb_info_global(this->global_elem_blk_ids,
795  this->global_elem_blk_cnts);
796 
797 
798  // Next, write global nodeset information to the file. This was already gathered in
799  // step II. above.
800  this->num_global_node_df_counts.clear();
801  this->num_global_node_df_counts.resize(this->global_nodeset_ids.size()); // distribution factors all zero...
802  this->put_ns_param_global(this->global_nodeset_ids,
803  this->num_global_node_counts,
804  this->num_global_node_df_counts);
805 
806 
807  // Next, write global sideset information to the file. This was already gathered in
808  // step III. above.
809  this->num_global_side_df_counts.clear();
810  this->num_global_side_df_counts.resize(this->global_sideset_ids.size()); // distribution factors all zero...
811  this->put_ss_param_global(this->global_sideset_ids,
812  this->num_global_side_counts,
813  this->num_global_side_df_counts);
814 
815 
816  // Before we go any further we need to derive consistent node and
817  // element numbering schemes for all local elems and nodes connected
818  // to local elements.
819  //
820  // Must be called *after* the local_subdomain_counts map has been constructed
821  // by the compute_num_global_elem_blocks() function!
822  this->build_element_and_node_maps(pmesh);
823 
824  // Next step is to write "load balance" parameters. Several things need to
825  // be computed first though...
826 
827  // First we'll collect IDs of border nodes.
828  this->compute_border_node_ids(pmesh);
829 
830  // Next we'll collect numbers of internal and border elements, and internal nodes.
831  // Note: "A border node does not a border element make...", that is, just because one
832  // of an element's nodes has been identified as a border node, the element is not
833  // necessarily a border element. It must have a side on the boundary between processors,
834  // i.e. have a face neighbor with a different processor id...
835  this->compute_internal_and_border_elems_and_internal_nodes(pmesh);
836 
837  // Finally we are ready to write the loadbal information to the file
838  this->put_loadbal_param(this->num_internal_nodes,
839  this->num_border_nodes,
840  this->num_external_nodes,
841  this->num_internal_elems,
842  this->num_border_elems,
843  this->num_node_cmaps,
844  this->num_elem_cmaps);
845 
846 
847  // Now we need to compute the "communication map" parameters. These are basically
848  // lists of nodes and elements which need to be communicated between different processors
849  // when the mesh file is read back in.
850  this->compute_communication_map_parameters();
851 
852  // Write communication map parameters to file.
853  this->put_cmap_params(this->node_cmap_ids,
854  this->node_cmap_node_cnts,
855  this->elem_cmap_ids,
856  this->elem_cmap_elem_cnts);
857 
858 
859  // Ready the node communication maps. The node IDs which
860  // are communicated are the ones currently stored in
861  // proc_nodes_touched_intersections.
862  this->compute_node_communication_maps();
863 
864  // Write the packed node communication vectors to file.
865  this->put_node_cmap(this->node_cmap_node_ids,
866  this->node_cmap_proc_ids);
867 
868 
869  // Ready the node maps. These have nothing to do with communiction, they map
870  // the nodes to internal, border, and external nodes in the file.
871  this->compute_node_maps();
872 
873  // Call the Nemesis API to write the node maps to file.
874  this->put_node_map(this->node_mapi,
875  this->node_mapb,
876  this->node_mape);
877 
878 
879 
880  // Ready the element communication maps. This includes border
881  // element IDs, sides which are on the border, and the processors to which
882  // they are to be communicated...
883  this->compute_elem_communication_maps();
884 
885 
886 
887  // Call the Nemesis API to write the packed element communication maps vectors to file
888  this->put_elem_cmap(this->elem_cmap_elem_ids,
889  this->elem_cmap_side_ids,
890  this->elem_cmap_proc_ids);
891 
892 
893 
894 
895 
896 
897  // Ready the Nemesis element maps (internal and border) for writing to file.
898  this->compute_element_maps();
899 
900  // Call the Nemesis API to write the internal and border element IDs.
901  this->put_elem_map(this->elem_mapi,
902  this->elem_mapb);
903 
904 
905  // Now write Exodus-specific initialization information, some of which is
906  // different when you are using Nemesis.
907  this->write_exodus_initialization_info(pmesh, title_in);
908 } // end initialize()
libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::num_global_node_counts

Referenced by libMesh::ExodusII_IO::write_element_data().

1551 {
1552  if ((_run_only_on_proc0) && (this->processor_id() != 0))
1553  return;
1554 
1555  // Quick return if there are no element variables to write
1556  if (names.size() == 0)
1557  return;
1558 
1559  // Quick return if we have already called this function
1560  if (_elem_vars_initialized)
1561  return;
1562 
1563  // Be sure that variables in the file match what we are asking for
1564  if (num_elem_vars > 0)
1565  {
1566  this->check_existing_vars(ELEMENTAL, names, this->elem_var_names);
1567  return;
1568  }

1571  // initialize_element_variables()

1575 
1576  // Form the element variable truth table and send to Exodus.
1577  // This tells which variables are written to which blocks,
1578  // and can dramatically speed up writing element variables
1579  //
1580  // We really should initialize all entries in the truth table to 0
1581  // and then loop over all subdomains, setting their entries to 1
1582  // if a given variable exists on that subdomain. However,
1583  // we don't have that information, and the element variables
1584  // passed to us are padded with zeroes for the blocks where
1585  // they aren't defined. To be consistent with that, fill
1586  // the truth table with ones.
1587  std::vector<int> truth_tab(num_elem_blk*num_elem_vars, 1);
1588  ex_err = exII::ex_put_elem_var_tab(ex_id,
1589  num_elem_blk,
1590  num_elem_vars,
1591  &truth_tab[0]);
1592  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error writing element truth table.");
1593 }

void libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::initialize_nodal_variables ( std::vector< std::string >  names)

libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::write_var_names
void write_var_names(ExodusVarType type, std::vector< std::string > &names)
Definition: exodusII_io_helper.C:940
libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::num_nodal_vars

libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::nemesis_err_flag
int nemesis_err_flag
Definition: nemesis_io_helper.h:319
void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::put_loadbal_param ( unsigned  num_internal_nodes,
unsigned  num_border_nodes,
unsigned  num_external_nodes,
unsigned  num_internal_elems,
unsigned  num_border_elems,
unsigned  num_node_cmaps,
unsigned  num_elem_cmaps 
)

Writes load balance parameters, some of which are described below: .) num_internal_nodes - nodes "wholly" owned by the current processor .) num_border_nodes - nodes local to a processor but residing in an element which also has nodes on other processors .) num_external_nodes - nodes that reside on other processors but whose element "partially" resides on the current processor – we assert this should be zero on reading! .) num_border_elems - elements local to this processor but whose nodes reside on other processors as well. .) processor - ID of the processor for which information is to be written

References libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ex_id, nemesis_err_flag, and libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id().

libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::nemesis_err_flag
int nemesis_err_flag
Definition: nemesis_io_helper.h:319
void libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::put_node_cmap ( std::vector< std::vector< int > > &  node_cmap_node_ids,
std::vector< std::vector< int > > &  node_cmap_proc_ids 
)

Outputs all of the nodal communication maps for this processor. Internally, this function loops over all communication maps and calls Nemesis::ne_put_node_cmap() for each one.

.) node_cmap_node_ids = Nodal IDs of the FEM nodes in this communication map .) node_cmap_proc_ids = processor IDs associated with each of the nodes in node_ids

In the Nemesis file, these all appeart to be written to the same chunks of data: n_comm_nids and n_comm_proc, but don't rely on these names...

Note: this class contains vector<vectors>: node_cmap_node_ids node_cmap_proc_ids which can be used when calling this function.

Must be called after put_cmap_params().

Definition at line 586 of file nemesis_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ex_id, nemesis_err_flag, node_cmap_ids, libMesh::out, libMesh::ParallelObject::processor_id(), and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by initialize().

594  {
595  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] put_node_cmap() : nodes communicated to proc "
596  << this->node_cmap_ids[i]
597  << " = ";
598  for (unsigned j=0; j<node_cmap_node_ids_in[i].size(); ++j)

1003  unsigned var_index = 0;
1004  bool found = false;
1005 
1006  // Do a linear search for nodal_var_name in nodal_var_names

1009  {
1010  found = true;
1011  break;

1013

1031  &num_elem_this_blk,
1032  NULL,
1033  NULL);
1034  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error getting number of elements in block.");
1035 
1036  std::vector<Real> block_elem_var_values(num_elem);
1037  ex_err = exII::ex_get_elem_var(ex_id,
1038  time_step,
1039  var_index+1,
1040  block_ids[i],
1041  num_elem_this_blk,
1042  &block_elem_var_values[0]);
1043  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error getting elemental values.");
1044 
1045  for (unsigned j=0; j<static_cast<unsigned>(num_elem_this_blk); j++)
1046  {
1047  // Use the elem_num_map to obtain the ID of this element in the Exodus file,
1048  // and remember to subtract 1 since libmesh is zero-based and Exodus is 1-based.
1049  unsigned mapped_elem_id = this->elem_num_map[ex_el_num] - 1;
1050 
1051  // Store the elemental value in the map.
1052  elem_var_value_map[mapped_elem_id] = block_elem_var_values[j];
1053 
1054  // Go to the next sequential element ID.
1055  ex_el_num++;
1056  }
1057  }
1058 }

void libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::read_qa_records ( )
inherited

Reads the QA records from an ExodusII file. We can use this to detect when e.g. CUBIT 14+ was used to generate a Mesh file, and work around certain known bugs in that version.

Definition at line 368 of file exodusII_io_helper.C.

References libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ex_err, ex_get_qa(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::ex_id, EX_INQ_QA, libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::inquire(), libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::is_cubit14_plus, libMesh::out, and libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::verbose.

Referenced by libMesh::ExodusII_IO::read().

369 {
370  // The QA records are four MAX_STR_LENGTH-byte character strings.
371  int num_qa_rec =
372  this->inquire(exII::EX_INQ_QA, "Error retrieving number of QA records");
373 
374  if (verbose)
375  libMesh::out << "Found "
376  << num_qa_rec
377  << " QA record(s) in the Exodus file."
378  << std::endl;
379 
380  if (num_qa_rec > 0)
381  {
382  // How to dynamically allocate an array of fixed-size char* arrays in C++.
383  // http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8529359/creating-a-dynamic-sized-array-of-fixed-sized-int-arrays-in-c
384  typedef char * inner_array_t[4];
385  inner_array_t * qa_record = new inner_array_t[num_qa_rec];
386 
387  for (int i=0; i<num_qa_rec; i++)
388  for (int j=0; j<4; j++)
389  qa_record[i][j] = new char[MAX_STR_LENGTH+1];
390 
391  ex_err = exII::ex_get_qa (ex_id, qa_record);
392  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error reading the QA records.");
393 
394  // Print the QA records
395  if (verbose)
396  {
397  for (int i=0; i<num_qa_rec; i++)
398  {
399  libMesh::out << "QA Record: " << i << std::endl;
400  for (int j=0; j<4; j++)
401  libMesh::out << qa_record[i][j] << std::endl;
402  }
403  }
404 
405  // Detect whether the file we're reading was generated by
406  // Cubit-14+, and set a flag on the helper if so.
407  for (int i=0; i<num_qa_rec; i++)
408  {
409  if (std::string(qa_record[i][0]).find("CUBIT") != std::string::npos)
410  {
411  // Try to convert field [1] of this QA record to a number.
412  char* endptr;
413  long cubit_version = std::strtol(qa_record[i][1], &endptr, /*base=*/10);
414 
415  // If there were no digits at all, strtol stores the
416  // input value in endptr. In that case, we won't assume
417  // this is a Cubit 14+ file...
418  if (endptr != qa_record[i][1])
419  {
420  if (verbose)
421  libMesh::out << "Detected Cubit major version " << cubit_version << std::endl;
422 
423  if (cubit_version >= 14)
424  is_cubit14_plus = true;
425  }
426  }
427  }
428 
429 
430  // Clean up dynamically-allocated memory
431  for (int i=0; i<num_qa_rec; i++)
432  for (int j=0; j<4; j++)
433  delete [] qa_record[i][j];
434 
435  delete [] qa_record;
436  }
437 }
ex_get_qa
EXODUS_EXPORT int ex_get_qa(int exoid, char *qa_record[][4])

2369  // Loop over all blocks, even if we don't have elements in each block.
2370  // If we don't have elements we need to write out a 0 for that block...
2371  for (unsigned int i=0; i<static_cast<unsigned>(this->num_elem_blks_global); ++i)
2372  {

2374  std::map<int, std::vector<int> >::iterator it =

2376

2378  if (it == this->block_id_to_elem_connectivity.end())
2379  {
2380  this->ex_err = exII::ex_put_elem_block(this->ex_id,
2381  this->global_elem_blk_ids[i],
2382  "Empty",
2383  0, /* n. elements in this block */
2384  0, /* n. nodes per element */
2385  0); /* number of attributes per element */
2386 
2387  EX_CHECK_ERR(this->ex_err, "Error writing element block from Nemesis.");
2388  }
2389 
2390  // Otherwise, write the actual block information and connectivity to file
2391  else
2392  {
2393  subdomain_id_type block =
2394  cast_int<subdomain_id_type>((*it).first);
2395  std::vector<int> & this_block_connectivity = (*it).second;
2396  std::vector<unsigned int> & elements_in_this_block = subdomain_map[block];
2397 
2398  ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps em(*this);
2399 
2400  //Use the first element in this block to get representative information.
2401  //Note that Exodus assumes all elements in a block are of the same type!
2402  //We are using that same assumption here!
2403  const ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion conv =
2404  em.assign_conversion(mesh.elem(elements_in_this_block[0])->type());
2405 
2406  this->num_nodes_per_elem = mesh.elem(elements_in_this_block[0])->n_nodes();
2407 
2408  ex_err = exII::ex_put_elem_block(ex_id,
2409  block,
2410  conv.exodus_elem_type().c_str(),
2411  elements_in_this_block.size(),
2412  num_nodes_per_elem,
2413  0);
2414  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error writing element block from Nemesis.");
2415 
2416  ex_err = exII::ex_put_elem_conn(ex_id,
2417  block,
2418  &this_block_connectivity[0]);
2419  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error writing element connectivities from Nemesis.");
2420  }
2421  } // end loop over global block IDs
2422 
2423  // Only call this once, not in the loop above!
2424  ex_err = exII::ex_put_elem_num_map(ex_id,
2425  exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh.empty() ? NULL : &exodus_elem_num_to_libmesh[0]);
2426  EX_CHECK_ERR(ex_err, "Error writing element map");
2427 }

2021 {
2022  // Write the nodesets. In Nemesis, the idea is to "create space" for the global
2023  // set of boundary nodesets, but to only write node IDs which are local to the current
2024  // processor. This is what is done in Nemesis files created by the "loadbal" script.
2025 
2026  // Store a map of vectors for boundary node IDs on this processor.
2027  // Use a vector of int here so it can be passed directly to Exodus.
2028  std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> > local_node_boundary_id_lists;
2029  typedef std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> >::iterator local_node_boundary_id_lists_iterator;
2030

2032  // did not have the libmesh to exodus node mapping at that time... for now we'll just
2033  // build it here again, hopefully it's small relative to the size of the entire mesh.
2034  std::vector<dof_id_type> boundary_node_list;
2035  std::vector<boundary_id_type> boundary_node_boundary_id_list;
2036  mesh.get_boundary_info().build_node_list
2037  (boundary_node_list, boundary_node_boundary_id_list);
2038 
2039  if (verbose)
2040  {
2041  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] boundary_node_list.size()="
2042  << boundary_node_list.size() << std::endl;
2043  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] (boundary_node_id, boundary_id) = ";
2044  for (unsigned i=0; i<boundary_node_list.size(); ++i)
2045  {
2046  libMesh::out << "(" << boundary_node_list[i] << ", " << boundary_node_boundary_id_list[i] << ") ";
2047  }
2048  libMesh::out << std::endl;
2049  }
2050 
2051  // For each node in the node list, add it to the vector of node IDs for that
2052  // set for the local processor. This will be used later when writing Exodus
2053  // nodesets.
2054  for (unsigned i=0; i<boundary_node_list.size(); ++i)
2055  {
2056  // Don't try to grab a reference to the vector unless the current node is attached
2057  // to a local element. Otherwise, another processor will be responsible for writing it in its nodeset.
2058  std::map<int, int>::iterator it = this->libmesh_node_num_to_exodus.find( boundary_node_list[i] );
2059 
2060  if ( it != this->libmesh_node_num_to_exodus.end() )
2061  {
2062  // Get reference to the vector where this node ID will be inserted. If it
2063  // doesn't yet exist, this will create it.
2064  std::vector<int>& current_id_set = local_node_boundary_id_lists[ boundary_node_boundary_id_list[i] ];
2065 
2066  // Push back Exodus-mapped node ID for this set
2067  // TODO: reserve space in these vectors somehow.
2068  current_id_set.push_back( (*it).second );
2069  }
2070  }
2071 
2072  // See what we got
2073  if (verbose)
2074  {
2075  for (std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> >::iterator it = local_node_boundary_id_lists.begin();
2076  it != local_node_boundary_id_lists.end();
2077  ++it)
2078  {
2079  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id() << "] ID: " << (*it).first << ", ";
2080 
2081  std::vector<int>& current_id_set = (*it).second;
2082 
2083  // Libmesh node ID (Exodus Node ID)
2084  for (unsigned j=0; j<current_id_set.size(); ++j)
2085  libMesh::out << current_id_set[j]
2086  << ", ";
2087 
2088  libMesh::out << std::endl;
2089  }
2090  }
2091 
2092  // Loop over *global* nodeset IDs, call the Exodus API. Note that some nodesets may be empty
2093  // for a given processor.
2094  for (unsigned i=0; i<this->global_nodeset_ids.size(); ++i)
2095  {
2096  if (verbose)
2097  {
2098  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
2099  << "] Writing out Exodus nodeset info for ID: " << global_nodeset_ids[i] << std::endl;
2100  }
2101 
2102  // Convert current global_nodeset_id into an exodus ID, which can't be zero...
2103  int exodus_id = global_nodeset_ids[i];
2104 
2105  /*
2106  // Exodus can't handle zero nodeset IDs (?) Use max short here since
2107  // when libmesh reads it back in, it will want to store it as a short...
2108  if (exodus_id==0)
2109  exodus_id = std::numeric_limits<short>::max();
2110  */
2111 
2112  // Try to find this boundary ID in the local list we created
2113  local_node_boundary_id_lists_iterator it =
2114  local_node_boundary_id_lists.find (cast_int<boundary_id_type>(this->global_nodeset_ids[i]));
2115 
2116  // No nodes found for this boundary ID on this processor
2117  if (it == local_node_boundary_id_lists.end())
2118  {
2119  if (verbose)
2120  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
2121  << "] No nodeset data for ID: " << global_nodeset_ids[i]
2122  << " on this processor." << std::endl;
2123 
2124  // Call the Exodus interface to write the parameters of this node set
2125  this->ex_err = exII::ex_put_node_set_param(this->ex_id,
2126  exodus_id,
2127  0, /* No nodes for this ID */
2128  0 /* No distribution factors */);
2129  EX_CHECK_ERR(this->ex_err, "Error writing nodeset parameters in Nemesis");
2130 
2131  }
2132  else // Boundary ID *was* found in list
2133  {
2134  // Get reference to the vector of node IDs
2135  std::vector<int>& current_nodeset_ids = (*it).second;
2136 
2137  // Call the Exodus interface to write the parameters of this node set
2138  this->ex_err = exII::ex_put_node_set_param(this->ex_id,
2139  exodus_id,
2140  current_nodeset_ids.size(),
2141  0 /* No distribution factors */);
2142 
2143  EX_CHECK_ERR(this->ex_err, "Error writing nodeset parameters in Nemesis");
2144 
2145  // Call Exodus interface to write the actual node IDs for this boundary ID
2146  this->ex_err = exII::ex_put_node_set(this->ex_id,
2147  exodus_id,
2148  &current_nodeset_ids[0]);
2149 
2150  EX_CHECK_ERR(this->ex_err, "Error writing nodesets in Nemesis");
2151 
2152  }
2153  } // end loop over global nodeset IDs
2154 }

virtual

Writes the sidesets for this processor.

Reimplemented from libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper.

2160 {
2161  // Write the sidesets. In Nemesis, the idea is to "create space" for the global
2162  // set of boundary sidesets, but to only write sideset IDs which are local to the current
2163  // processor. This is what is done in Nemesis files created by the "loadbal" script.
2164  // See also: ExodusII_IO_Helper::write_sidesets()...
2165 
2166 
2167  // Store a map of vectors for boundary side IDs on this processor.
2168  // Use a vector of int here so it can be passed directly to Exodus.
2169  std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> > local_elem_boundary_id_lists;
2170  std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> > local_elem_boundary_id_side_lists;
2171  typedef std::map<boundary_id_type, std::vector<int> >::iterator local_elem_boundary_id_lists_iterator;
2172 
2173  ExodusII_IO_Helper::ElementMaps em(*this);
2174

2181  (bndry_elem_list, bndry_side_list, bndry_id_list);
2182 
2183  // Integer looping, skipping non-local elements
2184  for (unsigned i=0; i<bndry_elem_list.size(); ++i)
2185  {
2186  // Get pointer to current Elem
2187  const Elem* elem = mesh.elem(bndry_elem_list[i]);
2188 
2189  std::vector<const Elem*> family;
2190 #ifdef LIBMESH_ENABLE_AMR
2191  // We need to build up active elements if AMR is enabled and add
2192  // them to the exodus sidesets instead of the potentially inactive "parent" elements
2193  // Technically we don't need to "reset" the tree since the vector was just created.
2194  elem->active_family_tree_by_side(family, bndry_side_list[i], /*reset tree=*/false);
2195 #else
2196  // If AMR is not even enabled, just push back the element itself
2197  family.push_back( elem );
2198 #endif
2199 
2200  // Loop over all the elements in the family tree, store their converted IDs
2201  // and side IDs to the map's vectors. TODO: Somehow reserve enough space for these
2202  // push_back's...
2203  for (unsigned int j=0; j<family.size(); ++j)
2204  {
2205  const dof_id_type f_id = family[j]->id();
2206  const Elem *f = mesh.elem(f_id);
2207 
2208  // If element is local, process it
2209  if (f->processor_id() == this->processor_id())
2210  {
2211  const ExodusII_IO_Helper::Conversion conv = em.assign_conversion(f->type());
2212 
2213  // Use the libmesh to exodus datastructure map to get the proper sideset IDs
2214  // The datastructure contains the "collapsed" contiguous ids.
2215  //
2216  // We know the parent element is local, but let's be absolutely sure that all the children have been
2217  // actually mapped to Exodus IDs before we blindly try to add them...
2218  std::map<int,int>::iterator it = this->libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus.find( f_id );
2219  if (it != this->libmesh_elem_num_to_exodus.end())
2220  {
2221  local_elem_boundary_id_lists[ bndry_id_list[i] ].push_back( (*it).second );
2222  local_elem_boundary_id_side_lists[ bndry_id_list[i] ].push_back(conv.get_inverse_side_map( bndry_side_list[i] ));
2223  }
2224  else
2225  libmesh_error_msg("Error, no Exodus mapping for Elem " \
2226  << f_id \
2227  << " on processor " \
2228  << this->processor_id());
2229  }
2230  }
2231  }
2232 
2233 
2234  // Loop over *global* sideset IDs, call the Exodus API. Note that some sidesets may be empty
2235  // for a given processor.
2236  for (unsigned i=0; i<this->global_sideset_ids.size(); ++i)
2237  {
2238  if (verbose)
2239  {
2240  libMesh::out << "[" << this->processor_id()
2241  << "] Writing out Exodus sideset info for ID: " << global_sideset_ids[i] << std::endl;
2242  }
2243 
2244  // Convert current global_sideset_id into an exodus ID, which can't be zero...
2245  int exodus_id = global_sideset_ids[i];
2246

2269  0, /* No sides for this ID */
2270  0 /* No distribution factors */);
2271  EX_CHECK_ERR(this->ex_err, "Error writing sideset parameters in Nemesis");

2273  }

2275  {
2276  // Get iterator to sides vector as well
2277  local_elem_boundary_id_lists_iterator it_sides =
2278  local_elem_boundary_id_side_lists.find (cast_int<boundary_id_type>(this->global_sideset_ids[i]));

std::map<int, std::vector<int> > libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::block_id_to_elem_connectivity

This is the block connectivity, i.e. for each subdomain (block) there is an element connectivity list. This map associates the block ID to that vector.

std::vector<int> libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::global_nodeset_ids

Containers for reading global nodeset information. One vector entry per nodeset. Each vector will eventually have num_node_sets_global entries, and will be used in calls to Nemesis::ne_get_ns_param_global().

It's an error to call ne_get_ns_param_global when num_node_sets_global==0

bool libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::is_cubit14_plus
inherited

Flag which is true if the file we're reading was generated by Cubit-14 or higher. We can use this flag to work around an issue where TRI3 elements in 3D have misnumbered sidesets (numbering is based on the TRISHELL side numbering). So far this bug has been confirmed to exist in both Cubit 14 and 15.

Definition at line 555 of file exodusII_io_helper.h.

Referenced by libMesh::ExodusII_IO_Helper::read_qa_records().

int libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::nemesis_err_flag

std::vector<std::vector<int> > libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::node_cmap_node_ids

2 vectors of vectors for storing the node communication IDs for this processor. There will be num_node_cmaps rows, row i will have node_cmap_node_cnts[i] entries. To be used with Nemesis::ne_get_node_cmap().

int libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::num_proc_in_file

The number of processors for which the NEMESIS I file stores information. This is generally equal to 1 (1 CPU/file) at least for the splitting Derek gave us. To be used with Nemesis::ne_get_init_info().

std::map<unsigned, std::set<unsigned> > libMesh::Nemesis_IO_Helper::proc_nodes_touched_intersections
private

Another map to store sets of intersections with each other processor (other than ourself, of course). A node which appears in one of these vectors belongs to element owned by at least this processor and one other.
